sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Read it again.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: —This is dated the 16th of April in the Sixth Year of Edward the Sixth. To all faithful—

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Certainly, my Lord, he is under a Mistake.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Ay, so he is sure enough, but a very foul one upon my Word: But let us see if we can bring him out of it. Mr. Banister, let me ask you a Question.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, if you please.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Then pray mind what I say, and consider of it. The 16th of September, 1682. was the time that you went on purpose to look for Deeds at Mr. Knowles's House?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I was there on the 7th Day of September, and that was the first Day that ever I came into Mr. Knowles's House in my Life.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: There were some Deeds, it seems, that Mr. Knowles had found before.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: So Mr. Knowles said.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What became of those Deeds he had found before?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: As he told me, he had mislaid them.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: And when did you come to have an account that he had found those Deeds first?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: It was after I had paid him 3 l. For Water.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: When was the first time that he spoke of it?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: It was the Fifth or Fourth of September.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: And when did you first go thither?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: On the 7th of September he desired me to come and help him and assist him in finding out the Deeds that he had mislaid.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: What do you know of this Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: We found one Deed—

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Look upon that Carefully, is that your Hand?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: That is my Hand.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Do you remember when you put your Hand to that Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: The Paper I have in my Hand was written at the same time.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Look upon that Paper, and consider it well, and now tell us whether you found that Deed first, or Mr. Knowles.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Mr. Knowles.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Now look upon it, and look upon it carefully, when was it?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: This Deed came into my Hands the same day that I writ this Note.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we desire we may go on with our Evidence, and not have them break in upon us to examine any such thing till their time comes; if they have any thing to object against our Witnesses, let them take their time.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, we are very regular sure in what we do; you produce a Deed, and we desire an account how you came by that Deed, and finding Mr. Banister's Name, who is your Witness, and sworn by you, we would know of him what he knows of it.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Aye, ay let Truth come out in God's Name. Look upon it Mr. Banister once more. What say you to it?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: This is the same Deed and my Hand.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Upon your Oath, Sir, when did you first see that Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: This Deed I saw the 7th of September, 1682.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: In the Garret at Mr. Knowles's House.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Did you find it first, or Mr. Knowles?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I cannot tell, it may be I might.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Are you sure you then put your Name to that Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I did put my hand upon this same Deed the 7th of September, 1682.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Pr'ythee look upon it again, and look very carefully upon it.

div.stage: Which he did for a good while together.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Now look upon your Note again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray do so, and peruse it carefully, and see whether that Deed be in your Note.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Nay, good Mr. Attorney, let us have no Directions. What say you?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I set my Hand to several Deeds that I found there, to some Writings, on the 7th of September, and to others on the 16th.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Now tell us which of them it was that thou didst put thy Hand upon this Deed.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I believe it might be the Seventh.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Didst thou not see that Deed before the Seventh of September, 1682. upon thy Oath?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: No, Never.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Who was with you when you first found that Deed?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, let this Note be read, and that will clear all.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: No, by no means, Mr. Attorney, he may make use of what Notes he pleases, to refresh his own Memory; but we will never support or prop up a Perjury at that rate, I assure you, by a Note. Was Mr. Knowles with you when you found that Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: He was.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Do you take it upon your Oath that that Deed was found the Seventh of September, 1682. in the Garret at Mr. Knowles's House?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I cannot tell which of the two, it was the Seventh or the Sixteenth.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Was it one of the two, upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: It was one of the two.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Now call Mr. Knowles again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: There he is, my Lord, if your Lordship please to look upon the Deed— Knowles's Name was to it likewise, but scraped out.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Well, we will ask him about it. But Mr. Banister positively swears he was at the finding of this Deed. What say you Knowles?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: I know nothing of it, my Name is not to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was your Name ever to it, or not?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: No, never.

sp.speaker: Mr. Dobbins.
sp.p: But it was to it at the Tryal in Michaelmas Term.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did you set your Name to all the Deeds you found in the Garret?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Upon your Oath, Banister, did you set your Name to any Deeds that he did not, that were found there?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I believe I might do so, I would not swear punctually to it.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Was he with you?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: He was with me in the very same Chamber.

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: I do not know that ever I put my Hand to that Deed in my Life.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did you ever see that Deed?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: I cannot say I did, I remember nothing of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: I ask you once again, when you found this Deed was he with you?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: You, Knowles, did you ever trust him to look and search any Deeds in your Garret, but when you were by your self?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Then I would ask you upon your Oath, because you are the Persons that had these Deeds in your Custody, was there any Deeds delivered out of your Hand that you did not set your Hand to?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: I believe there was never an one.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: How came this Deed which he swears was found there, not to have your Hand to it?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: I do not know that ever I saw it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did Mr. Knowles say he was looking for Deeds of his own concern when he found the first Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: He did say he had looked before, and had found some of these Deeds, and then mislaid them, and desired my Assistance to find them again.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What did he say to you at first?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: He said he had been spoken unto by my Lady Ivy, to look for deeds that might concern her Ancestors, and he had found some; but finding some also that concerned himself, he had mislaid my Ladys, and desired me to help him to find them again.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What Imployment have you under my Lady Ivy?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I am her Rent-gatherer.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Her Bayliff I suppose: But now you speak of what my Lady Ivy desired of Knowles, I would ask you a Question, lest it slip out of my Memory. Were you present at any time when my Lady Ivy spoke to Mr. Knowles to look after any Deeds?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes I was.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Pray tell us whose Deeds she desired him to look?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: The Deeds he said he had mislaid.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What were they?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: The Deed of Richard Hill, and the Deeds belonging to Stepney and Shadwel.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What Names did she mention to him, that she would have looked after?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: She did mention some.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Upon your Oath did she mention any Deeds made by Dr. Donne Dean of St. Paul?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: By one May Dean of St. Pauls.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Was one Lun named?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Or one Holder?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Not that I know of.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did she mention one Ioan Hall?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I do not know that my Lady Ivy gave particular order for any of these Names.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did she upon your Oath name Marcellus Hall to you?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: No, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Upon your Oath Knowles, was not he by when my Lady named Marcellus Hall to you?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: He was, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I did not hear my Lady name that Name at all.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: No, he heard her give Order for no particular Deeds, neither for Holder, nor Lunne, nor Marcellus Hall, but only concerning Stepney and Shadwell.

sp.speaker: Sir Edw. Herbert. Banister,
sp.p: Did he say he had before found them and mislaid them?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Upon your Oath what Deed do you take that to be, which is produced?

sp.speaker: Mr. Powis.
sp.p: Can you read it, yea or no?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Mr. Powis, Do you think my Lady Ivy sent Banister to look after Deeds that could not read? that were very pretty.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What Deed do you take it to be?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Let me ask you one Question, Mr. Banister, Did you ever set your hand to any Deeds that were not found at Mr. Knowles's?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes, I have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Lutwich.
sp.p: Upon what occasion did you put your hand to them?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Because they were ancient Deeds, and I was to look out where the Lands were that they did concern.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray now answer my Question, look upon it, and tell me what Deed do you take it to be?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: It is a Deed of Sale to Stepkins.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: It is so, you are in the right of it; and now upon your Oath, where did you find that Deed of Sale?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: My hand is to it, and this is one of the Deeds, I take it to be so, that was found in the Garret at Mr. Knowles's House.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: He has said so I know not how often.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: He is not himself.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: How can I help that Mr. Attorney? but what he says is plain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray read over the Note you have in your hand to yourself, and remember all the Deeds that are particularly therein contained.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Let him read his Note, (which he did) and now ask him what you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Is there any Deed of the Sixteenth of April, 6 Edw. 6. from Hill to Stepkins in that Note.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: That is no fair Question Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: With your favour my Lord, I conceive it is, for that will make it plain that he is mistaken.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: I believe he is; but with your favour, it is not a fair Question, you are only to ask him, whether that Deed given in Evidence be there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: I would ask him one short question, my Lord, and I think it is a fair one.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Ay in Gods name ask what fair questions you will, but no leading ones.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Your Witness is drunk Madam.—to my Lady Ivy.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Lutwich.
sp.p: My Lord, he does not understand what he says, that is plain.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Brother, all Knaves are Fools in one kind too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Have you read the date of that Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, if you please, we will go on with our other Evidence a while, and let him recollect himself and consider of it.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: With all my heart, but I think the more he considers, the worse he is, and so he will be to the end of the Chapter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: They have called to us, my Lord, for an account of this Deed, we shall now prove that Mr. Neale knew of this Deed before. Swear Mr. Butler, (which was done.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What is your Name?

sp.speaker: Mr Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir will you tell the Court and the Jury, what Discourse you had with Mr. Neale, and what he said about a Deed, and when.

sp.speaker: Butler.
sp.p: I never saw the Lease, but as I was here at the last Tryal, when there was a Verdict for this Estate to be my Lady Ivy's, and afterwards the 22 of December last, I had an opportunity of being with Mr. Neale, he being with Mr. Brian my Ladies Husband since dead, at the Kings head Tavern, with whom I had some business. Mr. Brian was there first (I suppose it was by appointment they met) and in half an hour Mr. Neale came up stairs; after they had changed two or three Complements, they came to talk about meeting at Mr. Attorney Generals Chamber in the Temple, to Treat about their Controversie. Says Mr. Neale, let there be a Forfeiture upon it of 50 l. to be paid by him that faills. No, says Mr. Brian I will make no forfeiture, but I will certainly meet there. Says Mr. Neale again, and I question not but to give such satisfaction as whereby to convince you and my Lady, that this is not her Estate. I should be glad to hear that, says Mr. Brian, why I hope you do not think the Deeds are Forged? No, says Mr. Neale, I do not think they are forged. Mr. Knowles offered me a long time ago, to shew me that Deed, and I might have had it in my possession, but I would not; for if I had, I should have been the aptest man in the world to burn it. This is all I can say.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: And what is this to the purpose Gentlemen, alack a day this is very thin. A slight Discourse in a Tavern; how can any answer be given to such an Evidence, tho' indeed it does not need any; pray let not our time be taken up with such trifling stories of a cock and a bull. Go on to that which is material.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now we shall produce a Lease from Marcellus Hall, to one Roper, of part of this Eleven Acres and an half.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: This Indenture made the 13 day of November, in the 2d and 3d years of the Reigns of our Soveraign Lord and Lady Philip and Mary, by the Grace of God King and Queen of England, Spain, France, both the Sicilies, Ierusalem, and Ireland, Defenders of the Faith, Arch-Dukes of Austria, Dukes of Burgundy, Millain and Brabant, Countess of Hasburg, Flanders and Tyrole, between Marcellus Hall of Radcliff Miller, of the one party, and Richard Roper Citizen and Salter of London, of the other party, witnesseth, That the said Marcellus Hall for the sum of Six pounds of good and lawful Money of England, to him by the said Richard Roper in hand paid, whereof the said Marcellus Hall clearly acquitteth and dischargeth the said Richard Roper, his Executors and Assigns, and every of them by these presents, hath granted, demised, and to farm letten, and by these presents granteth, demiseth, and to farm letteth, to the said Richard Roper, a parcel of Marsh Ground lying and being in Waping Marsh, at the East end of the Marsh, beginning at the west side of the Well, which lyeth by the way that leadeth up to the Linches, called Shadwel, measured by a strait line from the Linches, by the west side of the Well to the Thames Wall, and reaching West to the way that leadeth up into Radcliff high way, containing by estimation of Measure Seven Acres, little more or less, and the Pond, all which Marsh Land abutteth North upon the Linches of the Deart and Chapter of the Cathedral Church of St. Paul, and South upon the Thames Wall; and also all the Thames Wall belonging to the Seven Acres, with the Forland and Soyl down to the Low Water Mark of the River of Thames. All which Marsh Lands are lying in the Parish and Mannor of Stebunhith, alias Stepney, in the County of Middlesex. To have and to hold the said parcel of Marsh Ground, Wall, Fore-Land and Soyl, with the appurtenances, to the said Richard Roper, his Executors, and Assigns, from the Feast of the Annunciation of our blessed Lady St Mary the Virgin next coming, unto the end and term of Four and twenty years from thence next ensuing, and fully to be compleated and ended, yielding and paying therefore yearly, during the said Term, to the said Marcellus Hall, his Executors and Assigns, Three pounds of good and lawful money of England, at Four Terms of the year.—

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What date is that Deed of?

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: The 13th of November, in the 2d and 3d. years of King Philip and Queen Mary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now we shall read Stepkinses's Licence to Hall, to alien his Term.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p:
To all manner of People to whom this present writing shall come, I Thomas Stepkins, alias Stipkins, of the Parish of Stebunhith, alias Stepney, in the County of Middlesex Beer Brewer, send Greeting in our Lord God Everlasting. Whereas I the said Thomas Stepkins in the 16th of April, in the sixth year of Edward the sixth, have betaken Eleven Acres and an half of Marsh Land with all the Bank with the Foreland and Soyl down to the Low water mark of the River of Thames that he should not alien or assign the said Lease or Term of years, without the special license or consent Now know ye, That I the said Thomas Stepkins, for divers good causes give Leave and License to the said Marcellus Hall, to the Right Worshipful Mr Dean of the Cathedral Church of St. Paul with the Wall, Foreland, or Soyl
under such Covenants, as is reserved and contained—

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: I would ask Mr. Banister something about this Deed, look upon it Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We have not done with him yet. Pray take that Deed out of his hand.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: You will let him give some account of it first Mr. Attorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You would sain confound him.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: He is confounded enough already.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Now Mr. Banister you have considered of it, pray once more look upon the Deed again—(which he did)—Was that Deed one that you signed then or no?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: This is my name, but I cannot find the Date of this Deed in my paper. I cannot tell now whether it be one I found then or no.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Did you set your hand to any Deeds that were found there, which you did not set down in your paper.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: No, not that I know of, I do not know I did.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Prithee where didst thou set thy hand to that Deed.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I set my hand to the Deeds that were found there at the House.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did you set your hand to none else but what were found there?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I have set my hand to divers Deeds beside, but they are none of those Deeds that are in my paper.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Where did you set your hand to any Deeds besides?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: To divers Deeds I have set my hand at home.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Have you to any relating to the Lands in question?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I do not know that I have set my hand to any Deeds relating to the Lands in question, but at Mr. Knowles's.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: To what purpose did you set your Hand and Name to the Deeds you found at Knowles's.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: To the same intent to testifie that I was at the finding of them.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: To what end did you set your Hand to any other Deeds.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: To the intent that I knew better where the Lands did lye then she did, and when my Lady found any Deeds, I set my Hand to them, and then found the places where the Lands lay.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Thou hast had a fair time to consider of that Deed, canst thou see here to what place that Deed relates by this mark.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I cannot find the date of the Deed in my paper.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But where do you think you did put your name to that Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I cannot tell whether I did it at that time or no, but this is my Name.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: I know thy Name is there man, I read it two hours ago, but did you put your hand to that as one of the Deeds that you found in September, 1682. when you were at Mr. Knowles's or not?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Dost thou believe thou didst not?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Canst thou tell the reason why thou didst set thy hand to it?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Certainly because I was at the finding of it, I know no otherwise.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Now pray look upon this Deed— (shewing him another)—and see whether that be your Name or not.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, I will.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Is that your Name.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes it is, this is one of the Deeds that was found at Mr. Knowles's.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: You said so as to the other too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: But he was not so positive in it.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: This is Rat-eaten, and so I know it again, and there is a Rat-eaten Deed set down in my paper.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Lethim be as positive as he will, he has been forsworn five times.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: He was confounded with a mistake of the Deeds, he having set his hand to so many.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: They are Perjured both of them plainly, that is the truth of the matter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I hope the folly of our Witnesses in such Circumstances, shall not rob us of our own Land, and that it appears to be plainly.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: God forbid but you should have your own Land, but by the grace of God, if I can help it, you shall never have a foot of Land by Forswearing and Perjury.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: When did you find that Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: The 16th of September.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: In the Garret at Mr. Knowles's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Are you sure of it?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: Yes, I am sure of that Deed, because it is Rat-eaten.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Knowles, Pray do you look upon it, what say you to that Deed?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: This is my hand, and this is one of the Deeds that was found there at that time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray read the Date of that Deed there.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: This Indenture made the Thirteenth day of November, in the 2d. and 3d. Years of Philip and Mary.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: That is a Deed from Marcellus Hall to Roper; how should that come to be at Knowles's?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: They have sworn it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: They go about to blemish our Deeds by the Folly of our Witnesses, which we cannot help. We however leave the Deeds to the Jury, and let them see if those Seals and other things look like counterfeit.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Well, go on, the Jury will have the Deeds with them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, we did before produce a Conveyance from Richard Hill to Stepkins. It rested not there, that Conveyance had no legal Execution, thereupon there was a Fine and Recovery by the Heir of Hill, and what was the Occasion of that will appear by the Deed.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: This Indenture made the Twelfth day of November, in the First and Sixth Years of the Reigns of our Sovereign Lord and Lady, Philip and Mary, by the Grace of God King and Queen of England, Spain, France, both the Sicilies, Ierusalem and Ireland, Defenders of the Faith; Archdukes of Austria, Dukes of Burgundy, Millain, and Brabant, Counties of Haspurg, Flanders, and Tyrol: Between Iasper Hill, Son and Heir of Richard Hill, late Citizen and Mercer of London of the one Party; and Macheline Stepkins late Wife and Executrix of the last Will and Testament of Thomas Stepkin and Iohn Stepkin, Son and Heir apparent of the said Thomas of the other Party, witnesseth, that whereas the said Richard Hill, Father of the said Iasper amounting in the whole to the Summ of 2000 by the said Macheline And where variance concerning all that Parcel of Marsh-Land unto St. Katherines, which the said Richard Hill bought of Cornelius Vanderdelf for the assuring all that Wapping-Marsh the said Richard Hill stands Bound in an Obligation of which Condition that he should make by a certain Day, a good, sure, sufficient indefeasible of and in all those Parcels of Marsh-land lying in Wapping-marsh, that is to say, all that with Six Acres of Marsh, now in the Tenure or Occupation of one Knevett, or his Assignes and all those lying in the East and in the Tenure of one Miller, that is to say, all the Bank containing by estimation three Acres and an half, and all those next adjoining, by Measure six Acres or more and two Acres by Estimation of Measure, lying in the Bottom of the Lynches, and reacheth from the Lynches to the Island by the Pond; and also all that Parcel divided into twain six Acres, and also that holds in his own Hands, that is to say, all that Parcel with the Island and Pond, containing by Estimation of Measure five Acres and of, and in all those Parcels lying on the West side of the Pond containing in the whole sixteen Acres by Measure, all which said 16 Acres to Gravel-Lane, the said Richard Hill had in his own Occupation reaching to Gravel-Lane, sometime plowed and sown by one Richard Clayton, and now in the Occupation of one Cooper, Butcher, and lying on the East side of Gravel-lane towards London Fields which was conveyed to him from one Richard Tyrrell, and also all that Marsh in the Tenure of one Clayton, Butcher one William Cound, Butcher, seventeen Acres and of Edward Ash, four Acres, and also all the Lands, Tenements, Rents, Houses, Ponds, Fishings, Mills to the Low Water-mark of the River of Thames, and all Trees For the appeasing all Variances and Suits, the said Parties to this Indenture have fully condescended and agreed in Form following; that is to say, the said Iasper Hill, for the Sum of 1200 l. of lawful Money of England, in which he acknowledgeth himself to be truly indebted to the said Marcheline and Iohn Stepkin, doth give, grant, bargain, sell to the said Marcheline and Iohn Stepkin all the said Marsh-ground lying in Wapping-marsh, with all manner of Lands, Tenements Forelands, Ways, Trees to the Low Water-mark with the Appurtenances lying and being in without or elsewhere within the Parishes their Heirs and Assignes for ever, all the Right, Title together with all Evidences and Writings discharged of all former Charges, Incumberances by the said Iasper Hill —

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Next we shall shew that Marcellus Hall, that had this long Lease, and had demised the seven Acres down from Shadwell to Roper, doth on the 14th of Nov. in the 5th and 6th Years of Phil. and Mary, surrender the remaining four Acres to Thomas Stepkin, and then we shall shew it was demised to Fox, who was the first Builder, and made Foxes-lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Your Lordship doth observe that the License was to assigne the whole eleven Acres and an Half, but he did assigne but seven.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: This is dated in the 14th of November in the 5th and 6th Years of King Philip and Queen Mary.

To all to whom this present Writing shall come; I Marcellus Hall of Ratcliff, Miller, send greeting in our Lord God Everlasting. Whereas Thomas Stepkins hath by his Indenture dated the 20th Day of April, in the 6th Year of King Edward VI. lett to me the said Marcellus Hall on the West side with the Thames Wall thereto belonging, with the Foreland and Soyle for One Hundred and Twenty and Eight Years; Know ye, that I the said Marcellus Hall, for the Sum of 30l. of good and lawful Money of England in hand paid have by these Presents remised, released, and absolutely confirmed to the said Iohn Stepkin, his Heirs, Executors and Assignes, all such Estate, Right, Title, Interest, Term of Years, Estate, Property, Claim and Demand, which I, or any Person to my Use, have, or ought to have, or at any time shall to have in, or to four Acres of Marsh-Ground abutting East on the Green Bank, or Way through, Six Acres leading up to Ratcliff-Way, which Way adjoineth to the West side of the Lands in the occupying of Roper, which said Lands was made over with the Leave and License of the said Thomas Stepkins, to the Right Worshipful for the Term of Ninety Three Years; and West on the Field in the occupying of Iohn North on the Lynches, and South of in or to the Thames Wall abutting East, on the South-West Way, as aforesaid down to the Low Water-mark of the River of Thames So that neither I, my Executors, or Assignes any Right, Claim, Demand or any part thereof but from all shall be utterly excluded and debarred for Ever—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Here is a Fine levied, Quin' Trin' 3 Eliz. they had best ask where that was found too: Is not that forged?

div.stage: The Fine was read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Here is a Recovery also, and a Deed to lead the Uses. In which Recovery the Tenants vouch Iasper Hill, who voucheth over the common Vouchee.

div.stage: The Recovery was read.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Read your Deed to lead the Uses.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: This Indenture made the 12th Day of May, in the 4th Year of the Reign of our Sovereign Lady Elizabeth, by the Grace of God, Queen of England, France and Ireland; Defender of the Faith, &c. Between Marcheline Stepkin of the one Party; and Edward Buggin Where it was concluded, fully condescended and agreed between the Parties to this Indenture, that they the said Edward Buggin should in the Term of the Holy Trinity recover to them by Writ of Entry sur Disseisin in le Post, to be had against the said Macheline and Iohn, before the Queen's Majesty, Justices of the Common Pleas at Westminster, for that time, being according to the Use of former Recoveries One Hundred Acres of fresh Marsh, within the Parishes, Towns, Fields And it was fully agreed between the said Parties, that the said Recovery should be to the Uses

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Mr. Banister, Pray, Sir, look upon this Deed, and see whether your Name be to that Deed or no.

div.stage: [Shewing him the Surrender of Hall.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: This is my Name.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was Mr. Knowles's Hand to that Deed?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: M.S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Did not he and you put your Hands together to it?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I did not make it, I did not forge it.

sp.speaker: M.S. Pemberton.
sp.p: No, I do not think you did, you have not Brains to do it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Where did you find that Deed?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: How came you to put your Hand to it?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Is it one of the Deeds of Purchase?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Yes, it is, and therefore we would know since Knowles's Name is to it, how it came there.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Is it the Surrender made by Marcellus Hall to Iohn Stepkin?

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord it is.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Let me see it.—His Name I believe has been there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Do you know any thing of the rasing of it out?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: No not I.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You Knowles were you at the finding of that Deed?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: I set my Hand to none but what I found.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: But what do you say to that Deed?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: I do not remember this Deed at all, I cannot say any thing to it.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Was your Name to it?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Here is my Name, but I do not know who put it there.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Is that your Writing Banister.

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: That on the back side is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Look into your Note, that you may not outrun yourself. Why did you set your Hand to it?

sp.speaker: Banister.
sp.p: I suppose it was one of the Deeds found there.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How should it come there, it belonged to the Purchasor.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now we shall go to matter of Record again. Richard Hill it seems before the Lease made to Marcellus Hall, entred into a Recognizance in 4 Eliz. this is extended, and that will shew it to be Richard Hills's Estate.

sp.speaker: Mr. Powis.
sp.p: Can you object any Forgery of Records, pray.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray Sir look upon that (to the Witness) where did you Examine that?

sp.speaker: Witness.
sp.p: I examined this at the Rolls.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Is it a true Copy upon your Oath?

sp.speaker: Witness.
sp.p: It is.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Read it.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: This is Tested at Westminster 17 Ian. 4 Eliz. And here is an Inquisition taken the 6th of April in the same year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We will read that part of the Inquisition that concerns our Question, for the East bound is only in question now.

div.stage: (It was read.)

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was this produced at the former Tryal, the first Tryal.

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: No, I think not in Michaelmas Term.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Then we shall shew an Inquisition upon a Commission of Sewers.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The Land in question is every foot of it in the Marsh, and that they must acknowledge they have no Title to it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: This is an Inquisition which they produce taken before a Commission of Sewers. I desire to know how that comes to lye in a private Hand, for it is the original Inquisition, and ought to remain with the Officer.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The whole Interest of the Marsh was ours, therefore it might well be left with us.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: Under favour, good Mr. Attorney, such things should be kept by the Clerk to the Commissioners.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How many Tryals has this been produced at?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Pemberton.
sp.p: With submission my Lord, this that they produce being an Original, may very well come under great suspicion, in regard it ought to be brought in by the Officer, in whose Custody it ought to remain.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: It is not a thing of bare Interest between Party and Party, but a thing that concerns the Publick, and therefore should be brought in the Officers Custody.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Read it de bene esse, let us see what it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, I would ask Mr. Sutton, was not this produced and read before the the Trial in Michaelmas Term last?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: It was produced in Court Twelve years ago.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Was it allowed as Evidence?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: Yes, constantly.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray read it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray who has had it in keeping all this while?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: My Lady Ivy brought it to me among her Writings at first.

sp.speaker: L.C.I.
sp.p: Read it.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: The Verdict and Presentment of us the Jurors, as well of all Defects, Annoyances, within the Limits or Bounds of Wapping, and Wapping Marsh, from Grash Mill to the Mill at Ratcliff, that is to say, the 20th of December, Anno Dom. 1572. and in the 14th year of the Queens Majesties Reign that now is.
The Names of the Free-holders within Wapping Marsh, and the Number of Acres contained within the same Marsh, with all the Names of the Occupiers thereof.
First Iohn Stepkin Gent. Freeholder, for a parcel containing Twenty two Acres, in the Tenure of Richard Ew Benedict Gent.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: You may skip over a great deal, and read only that which conduce to the Question.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: No one can read it very well I think.
On the west side of Gravel-lane, containing 68 Acres.—Is that it?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No, go to the East side.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: —Freeholders, one parcel containing Ten Acres, in the Tenure of Iohn Hodges and Iohn Gee, Iohn Stepkin. Gent.
Two Parcels containing 20 Acres in the Tenure of Iohn Cooper, and Iohn Harding, Iohn Stepkin, Gent.
One Parcel containing Four Acres, in the Tenure of Iohn Stepkin.
One Parcel Containing Twelve Acres, in the Tenure of Iohn Roger Iames, Freeholder.
Two Parcels containing Six Acres, Robert Hemmings, and Iohn Stepkin.
One Parcel containing One Acre and an half, Richard Roper.
One Parcel containing Six Acres in the Tenure of Rechard Roper.
All which Parcels be on the East Part of Gravel-lane, containing Sixty Acres — Then here is somewhat interlined and struck out again.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: This doth not concern the Church.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No more it doth not, as you say, indeed, for they cannot claim any of the Marsh. Now we shall shew a Warrant Three Years after, from the Commissioners to survey.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: —This is dated the 18th of Iuly, in the 17th Year of the most prosperous Reign of our Sovereign Lady Elizabeth, by the Grace of God—&c. And it is directed,

To our well-beloved John Stepkin and John Osborn, Surveyors. Whereas, The Queen's Majesty by a Commission of Sewers, bearing Date the 23th Day of April, in the Year of her Reign, hath authorized us to survey and view from Buttolphs-Wharf by St. Katharines, near the Tower of London unto Ratcliff-mill not only to consider of the Decays and Ruines of the same; but also to take order for the speedy repairing as to our Discretions shall seem good We therefore sufficiently informed of your Wisdom and Discretion, appoint you Surveyors willing and commanding you by vertue of the said Commission to see whether the Work be accomplished according to such Ordinances and Decrees as we have appointed, and from time to time shall make and appoint, and to see who we have made Expenditor for such Sums of Money for the Payment of Workmen may by your Warrant be disbursed and payed accordingly; and further, we give you Power and Authority to give to provide for a competent and Salary at reasonable Prices, all Workmen▪ Boats, Lighters, Carts, Carriages, Trees, Pales as to your good Discretion shall seem meet; and for your so doing, this shall be your sufficient Warrant.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We shall now go a Step farther, as I opened in the beginning, and shew that this was mortgaged by Stepkins to the Queen, and a fine was levied upon that Mortgage.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p:
This Indenture made the 4th Day of Iune in the 15th Year of the Reign of our Sovereign Lady Elizabeth, &c. Between the Right Honourable Sir William Cecil, Knight; Lord Burleigh, and Lord High Treasurer of England; the Right Honourable and one of her Highness's most Honourable privy Council; Sir Gilbert Gerard, Knight; her Majesty's Attorney General, for and on the Behalf of the Queen's Majesty and to her use of the one Party, and Iohn Stepkin Whereas William Pat one of the Tellers at and upon the Determination of his Account made and ended at the 25th Day of December is indebted in the Summ of 7928 l. 7 s. and 11 d. ob. And whereas our said Sovereign Lady the Queen the 16th Day of Iune in the 9th Year of her Reign, hath commanded the said Sir Will. Cecil Sir Gilbert Gerard, and Sir Thomas Bromley to take order from time to time with so many of the Debts owing, or that after should be owing and for the sure Payment and Contentation of the said Summ of 7928 l. 7 s. 11 d. ob. Covenanteth with them the said that he the said Iohn Stepkin his Heirs, Executors shall and will not only saisfie and pay the said Summ into the Receipt aforesaid but also for the better Settlement shall and will make and cause to be made by one Fine
in good Form of Law of, and in one Close within the Parish Mannor of Yewel; and one great Garden And of, and in one Tenement with the Appurtenances in now in the occupation of Iohn Stout; and 19 Acres of Meadow in Wapping-marsh, Parcel of the said Mannor Richard Roper.

sp.speaker: Mr. Attorn. Gen.
sp.p: Where is the Copy of the Fine?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: Here.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: This is the Final Concord, &c. Mens. Mich. 14 Eliz.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: This was afterwards regranted from the Crown, and there is the Regrant.

div.stage: Which being under the great Seal, and Tested 6 Iulii Anno 7. Iacobi Rex was read.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Part of this Marsh was by our Ancestor conveyed to one East.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Ay, I have the Note of such a Conveyance, in my Notes of the last Tryal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Sutton, is that a true Copy?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: Yes, it is.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: A Copy of what? where did you examine it Sir?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: At the Roles-Chappel.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: It is a Deed enrolled, and I hope you do not think the Record is forged, Mr. Williams.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: I know not what you forge or do not forge; pray read it, let us see what it is.

div.stage: The Copy of a Deed enroled, dated 27 July, 3 Eliz. was read.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Then the next thing that you produced was a Bond dated the 25th of Ianuary, 4 Eliz. wherein Stepkins was bound to Spinola, who was Administrator of Vivold and Salvago, upon the Recognizance of Hill to them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We did so, my Lord; but that we cannot now readily find, I think: here however is Spinola's Discharge.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: This is Signed by me Benedict Spinola, and Dated the 25th of Feb. 1561.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Here is the Bond, read the Condition of it, though it is not material.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: That is true; But it was read the last time, I find by my Notes.

sp.speaker: Clerk.
sp.p: This is a Bond of 300 l. The Condition of this Obligation is such, that whereas one Recognizance made and entered into by Richard Hill 3 Dec. in the 32th Year of the late King Henry VIII. taken and acknowledged—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: There is enough, for it makes not at all to the purpose, but to confirm the Belief of our Purchase. Here is also Iasper Hill's Receipt of the Purchase Money.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: This is dated the 28th of Ianuary, in the 13th Year of Queen Elizabeth. Be it known unto all Men by these Presents, that I Iasper Hill of Wormley have had before the ensealing hereof, of Macheline and Iohn Stepkins for the discharge of a certain Statute the full Summ of 1338 l. of lawful Money of England, in full Satisfaction and Payment of all such Purchase Moneys.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then the 16th of Aug. 13 Iacobi, Fox, conveyed to Iohn Stepkins; but that is left at home.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Well, then there is an End of that, what do you do next?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We have done with our Evidence by Deeds and by Records, and now we shall come to our Evidence by Witnesses, Viva Voce. And first we shall begin with Mr. Knowles, who will will prove the Value of the Land by the Rents, and particularly what the Rents are of Derrick-Hills.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Prove what you will.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Mr. Knowles, have you received the Dean's Rents?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: For the use of Mr. Neale I have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What are the Rents of the East side of Cock-Hill?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: About 100 l. a Year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What are they?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Houses.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: All Houses?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Some Houses, some Ground Rents.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What is the Rack Rent?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: About 100 l. Year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Which Houses do you speak of, Mr. Knowles?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: On the East side of Cock-hill.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know the Lynches?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who receives the Rents of that Ground?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Mr. Neale did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Have you received the Rents of the Twenty Acres?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Yes; for Mr. Neale I have.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: These Three together, what are they all?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: About 2000 l. a Year.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: All this the Church of Pauls has besides the Lands in Question.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: You say that part is worth 100 l. a Year.

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Stringer.
sp.p: How much Land might it contain?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: It is a matter of the length of the Hall.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: And how broad is it?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Not very broad.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now then to come to the Lands in Question. Do you know Marriners-street?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Who is in Possession of that, and receives the Rents of it?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Mr. Neale.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What say you to Griffins-Alley?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: Some of it is in Mortgage; Mr. Babington had it, but for Mr. Neale's Use.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What say you to the Water-house?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: That Mr. Neale himself has.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: These are the things in Question. Do you know that which is called New?

sp.speaker: Knowles.
sp.p: That is Mr. Neale's too.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Our Lease of 128 Years expired but in the Year 1680. and we could not come at it till then: and we had it not till 1682. and that answereth their Possession.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Now we shall call our Witnesses to prove it Marsh-Ground. Swear Thomas Hughes— [Which was done.] —Do you know Wapping-Marsh?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know the Houses in Question?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: Which Houses?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: The Houses now in Suit for?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long have you known them?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: There was no Houses when I knew it first.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know Cock-hill?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Hughes,
sp.p: Yes; I did know it before it was built.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know the Houses that lay on the East side of Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: What Houses there?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know any Houses there formerly?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: I know not what you mean.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: I ask you again, do you know Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: Yes, it was a Bank before it was built.

sp.speaker: Mr. Powis.
sp.p: Do you know the Lynches?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Nay, let us ask but one at once, pray. I will ask you a plain Question; Did you know the Marsh before it was built upon?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, that I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How far did the Marsh-Ground go?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: To Cock-hill Eastward, as far as the broad Bridge; Westward as far as Foxes-lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was that all Marsh-Ground?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: The River of Thames did flow round about it, and there were Boggs, Trees and Bushes, and such things.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Lutwich.
sp.p: Did you know the place where Ratcliff-Mill stood?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: According to report I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Lutwich.
sp.p: Ay, where was that?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: Just at Bell-wharf.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Lutwich.
sp.p: Upon which side of Cock-hill?

sp.speaker: Hewes.
sp.p: In Shadwell-Hamlet.

sp.speaker: Mr. At. Gen.
sp.p: That is right.

sp.speaker: Mr. Powis.
sp.p: Was that like the other end of the Marsh?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: The River came in there wholly.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Lutwich.
sp.p: At high Flood doth the Water come in there at this time?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: It did at every Tide high and low formerly, now it is dam'd up.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did the Tide come up to that you call Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Then that makes an end of the Question: it cannot be as you say.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How so, my Lord?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: How could it be an overshot Mill? how could the Mill be turned but with the Tide?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Their Evidence makes it appear such by the Leaden Trough, which is an Instrument belonging only to an Over-shot Mill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Tell not me of the Leaden Trough, Mr. Attorney; look you upon the Survey you produced, and take Notice of the last Paragraph, and there you will find the Words Prox' adjacent' cuidam Tenemento, &c. What make you of that?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, let it be read.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p:
I will in the mean time ask your Witness a Question. Friend, thou seemest to
be a Man that understands something. Thou sayst Foxes-Idne was a Bank before it was built, and the Tide before that time came up to that Bank, both high and low. Now suppose there had been a Mill in that Ground, how should it have been driven?

sp.speaker: Hughes.
sp.p: I will tell your Honour; my Lord, by Report, and I suppose it may be true; the Mill stood all the Tide of Flood, and when the Flood was at High-Water, there was a Dam which kept it in, and it went out again at Ebb-Tide, and so the Mill was drove.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: There is your Overshot Mill gone then, Mr. Atorney.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: If ever Seven or Eight Acres of Gound can be the Appurtenances of a Mill, I should much wonder.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Mr Attorney, I can tell you of a Mill over against this Place, which I my self, and we all can remember. All the Estate about it was in the Traps Family, he was a Gentleman of our House; all the Water that drives that Mill, and two or three Mills that serve that side of the River, is taken in as the Tide comes in, and is pent in as he says by a Dam, and when they open that, the Mill turns back again. For I would sain have all these things that seem to be dark cleared by the way as they go. I will suppose all the Records you have read to be right, and that it is called Ratcliff-Mill, and then there is the Mill-bank, and the Hilly-bank, and the Hilly-way; it is plain then there was a Mill-bank, or a Hilly-bank, or whatever you call it. It so falls out that the thing now in Question is made plain upon your own Evidence, there was really Ponds, and Gutters, and those things that were to satisfie the Mill: This Mill comes to be plucked down, and the Ponds and all the Sleuces come now to be built upon: This is not like your Marsh Ground that is on the Western part of the Bank, but it is Parcel of Mere or Marsh, as the Pond and the rest stifled up by those things, that till such time as the Mill was taken away were Receptacles for to pen up the Water that came in with the Tide. What is the meaning of those Words in the Survey that I spoke of before, and the several Tenements and Orchards, and Ponds, and Sewers, &c. and all those things. Would you have it that this should all point to the Scite of the Mill, as though all the Boundaries should extend to the East end of the Mill?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Stringer.
sp.p: That was the Reason why I asked but now how big the whole was.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: And will what you would have, Mr. Attorney, a Ditch or two ever answer the Words in the Survey?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Nor will all their Words amount to divers Closes of Ground, as this must make in the whole.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Their Twenty Acres elsewhere; answers all they can claim.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But this you yourself say, is the Derrick-hills, in the Survey; and you do take it as soon as the Mill was pulled down in one place, it was set up in another.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: After he had taken our long Lease he erected one, we say, upon our Ground for he had pulled down the old Mill, and lett that to Carter.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: My Lord, it is plain that the old Mill and the new Mill were not upon the same Ground from Carter's Lease.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Mr. Sollicitor, You indeed agree among your selves that it is plain, but alas the Fact is quite contrary.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Maynard.
sp.p: My Lord, we do make our Argument for the Defendants Title as your Lordship does apprehend it. The Boundaries towards the East is made the Mill and Ratcliff-Town. This place that contains Seven Acres, though it had Passages for the Water, is not the Mill, and it can never be, that so much Ground can be reckoned to be Lands belonging to the Mill: It is the Mill it self that is the East bound.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: No, it is the Mill and the Mill Bank, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Maynard.
sp.p: With Submission, my Lord, it is Ratcliff-Mill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Is there no Mill-Bank in any of the Deeds?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Maynard.
sp.p: Not that I remember.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: At the Peril of my Discretion be that, Brother.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Maynard.
sp.p: Take it to be so as your Lordship says, that there is mention of a Mill-Bank, that cannot lye East, for it lyeth in a little Pond—

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Good Brother let us not puzzle that which is as plain as that the Sun shines. The controversy is about all the West part of Foxes-lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: No, it is the East bound that we contend for.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Mr. Attorney, if you will mistake the Point I cannot help it, I assure you I do not. Pray take notice of it, it is called 130 Acres in your Act of Parliament.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, 130 Acres.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Now then the East of your Land by your own shewing is Mill-Bank; the East of Mill-Bank is the Mill, whereas the West part is St. Katherines, so all your Deeds and Records say but the East part of the Land is Mill-Bank.

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Maynard.
sp.p: No, my Lord, Ratcliff-Mill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But I say, ay, Brother. Then how broad doth Foxes-lane extend?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: 'Tis reckoned 30 Foot in Carter's Lease, I think.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: That is a Lease that I perceive there is some controversy about, therefore I do not so much mind that: It is a Perch of Land I think in some of your Evidences.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where Foxes-lane is, is the four Acres that were surrender'd, now that being the West-bound of the eleven Acres, where then are the other seven?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Read the Deed Poll again, the particulars and Bounds only.

sp.speaker: Clerk
sp.p: All those my four and twenty Acres and an half—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: The East Bound your Lordship sees is the Mill: Now your Lordship makes an Objection, that if it were as we say, an Overshot Mill, it could not have been driven—

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Do not, pray, make any silly Objection for me, and then think to answer it. I tell you I do say, that it is impossible there could be any Mill there, but a Tide-Mill: The thing is as plain, Mr. Att. as any thing in the World can be Go on with your Evidence.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Pray swear Iohn Somerly— [Which was done]—How long have. you known the Place in Question?

sp.speaker: Somerly.
sp.p: I have known it about 27 or 28 Years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know where the Mill stood, or was reported to stand.

sp.speaker: Somerly.
sp.p: I know where it was reported to stand, but I never knew the Mill my self, it was demolished before my time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where was it reported to stand?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: As it was reported, it stood about half the length of the Hall off the Bank, rather leaning to the River of Thames than the High-way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where was the way to the Mill?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: At Cock-hill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: That your own Evidence say, was on the West side of the Mill.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know Shadwell?

sp.speaker: Somerly.
sp.p: I know that that is called Shadwell. Do you mean the Well?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes; how far is the Well from Cock-hill?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: Half the length of the Hall.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: How far is it East of Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: Truly I cannot well tell.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: The Question is, whether that be the Well that is mentioned in the Evidences?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: I never knew any other Well; I pay'd for filling of it up.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: What was it? was it not a Pond formerly?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: It was a Well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What was it called?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: Shadwell it was called, I knew no other Name it had; and that Well was wharfed about, and there was a Piece of Wood about Six Foot long put into it, and it was on the hide of the Hill, a Cooper had it in his Possession, and he used to put his Hoops into it—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember the Ditch that ran under the Lynches?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: I remember their was a Ditch that run along way, there were three or four Bridges over it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was that a wide Ditch?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: It had Planks to go over, and it was a deep Ditch.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When you knew it did Cattle feed there?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: Not in my time.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: When you first knew that Well was it reputed an ancient Well?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: I knew it not till I came to buy it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What do you know of the raising of Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: I lived there 26 Years ago, and in the time since I lived in it, it is raised the Length of my Stick and more: For when the Tyde came in strong, it used to drive Stones and Planks in at the Windows. There was a Waterhouse erected upon Wapping-Wall, and they went to lay Pipes along the Street, but they could not lay them there, for they found great Pieces of Timber, and other things in the Ground that hindered it, and upon that they raised the Ground.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was not there a Dam made at the End of Foxes-lane to keep out the Tide?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: I never knew of any.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Was not Foxes-lane reputed an ancient way?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: I suppose they were continually paving it to raise it higher and higher.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When you knew it first was it higher than the Marsh?

sp.speaker: Somerley.
sp.p: It was all built when I came thither. It is 6 Yards higher at one End than the other.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Iohn Holmes— [Which was done.]—Do you know the Houses in Question, between Foxes-lane and Cock-hill?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long have you known it?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: I have known the Place a matter of 28 Years, or more.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know it before it was built?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: No; I did not take notice of it, to say notice.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know that place that is called Shadwell?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: What do you know of the raising of Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: I never did know of raising the Lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Not at all?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Was it not all the time you knew it a common Passage?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: Yes; a common High-way.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Shew, if you can, that there was any High-way from North to South, but Foxes-lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know Cock-hill?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: That is quite off from it.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Let me ask you a Question. Suppose you were to go for the purpose from Shadwell down to the River of Thames, would you go to Cock-hill or Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: If I had occasion to go down to Pelican-stairs, then I would go to Foxes-lane; but if I were to go to Bell-wharf, I would go to Cock-hill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: That is quite another way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: It is Southward of Cock-hill where the Mill stood.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: That adjoined just upon the way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Doth not Cock-hill lead to the Thames?

sp.speaker: Holmes.
sp.p: Cock-hill is the first beginning of the going down to Bell-wharf.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Eleanor Barefoot, and Mary Day. [Eleanor Barefoot was sworn.] Do you know Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes, I know it very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How long have you known it?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Threescore and almost Six Years.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then you knew it before it was built?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know the old Mill?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Who, Sir?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember who first built there?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: I cannot tell.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Pray, when you knew it first, what was it, and whose?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: It was Marsh-ground from Cock-hill to Fenners-field it was counted and known to be Mr. Stepkin's, he was a great Free-holder, and owner of all the Ground up to East-Smithfield.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: How? Why is not the Lynches between Cock-hill and St. Katherines?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: The upper Ground was only belonging to the Dean of St. Pauls.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Do you remember that which is now called Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Was it a Lane at that time?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes, it was.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you remember how the Water came in there?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did it come up to the Bank?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: At high Tides it came over, that so that none could pass.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But at common Tides?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: It came at common Tides, till it was raised.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But it was an usual passage for Carts and Carriages?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How was the Mill driven that was there?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: There was a Mill in my time, that went with the Tide, and all the Water that came down from that Mill, came into a Pond, and so to the Mill-dam, and so drove this Mill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Which Mill dost thou speak of? Didst thou know Ratcliff-Mill?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know Cock-hill-Mill?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes; that I speak of.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: And how was it driven dost thou say?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: It was driven by the Water that came from the River in a Sluce.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: It came out of the Thames?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes; with the Tide.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: How did it run?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: It had a great huge Sluce.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was that in the Lynch Ditch, or otherway?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: It ran into a Pond.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where did that Pond stand?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: In New-Gravel-lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where was the Head of the Pond?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: It went out with the Tide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Between the Street and the Mill.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How near was the Pond to Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: A Quarter of a Mile off.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: West of Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Do you know Green-bank?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How far is that from Foxes-Lane?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Half a Mile off.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you know the Well called Shadwell?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes, I did.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sol. Gen.
sp.p: On which side of Foxes-lane did Shadwell stand?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: It was between the Mill and Broad-bridge; Eastward of Broad-bridge.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How far was it from the Mill?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: A pretty way.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How far do you think?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: About 40 or 60 Foot: The Well was between the Mill I say, and Broad-bridge, Foxes-lane stood West.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: When you knew Foxes-lane first, what was it between the Lynches on the North, and the Thames on the South?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: a Place for Carts and Horses to go.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And you say it was all Marsh-ground from Cock-hill to St. Katherines.

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Yes, it was all alow Ground.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Whose Ground was it counted to be?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: Mr. Stepkins's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Had the Dean ever any thing to do there?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: The upper Ground was the Dean of Paul's, but the lower Ground was Mr. Stepkins's.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Was there a Bridge over the Lynch Ditch at the end of Foxes-lane.

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: There was a Bridge and a Cart way.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Do you know it was Marsh-ground on the East side of Foxes-lane? did it ever lie under Water?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: At high Tides and such as that it was overflowed.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But at common Tides did it use to go over Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: I cannot tell that truly, it is now raised very high, it was much lower; but I am sure the Tide sometimes came beyond.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: When the Water was in the great Pond, did not it come by the Lynch Ditch.

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: It came out of the Thames.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Do you remember any way that led up to the Lynches by the Well?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: The Lynches did not belong to Mr. Stepkins; there was the Mill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But answer me, was there any way that went up to the Lynches by the Well?

sp.speaker: Barefoot.
sp.p: There was no Passage to go through, but at Foxes-lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was there not a Way at Cock-hill?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: That is farther East than the Mill.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Shadwell is the Bounds of our Land.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But where is that? that is the Question, Mr. Attorney. I remember what the Woman said indeed the last time, if there were as many Wells as there were Pains in the Glass Window here, that was the Right Well. But that will not decide the Controversy.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Austin Cope.— [Which was done.]—Do you know Cock-hill?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Yes, I do.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Did you not know a Mill that was at Ratcliff?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: There was one at Bell-wharf.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: How long ago is it that you remember it?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Threescore Years ago.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: How was that Mill driven?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: With the Tide.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Where did the Tide come in?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: At Frying-pan-stairs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Whither did it go?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: It went into the Dam, and so drove the Mill. There was an Iron Mill built by one White Twenty Years after.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: How far did the Tide go up from Ratcliff-Mill Westward?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: As near as you can remember, what was it that stopped the Tide?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Ay, how far did the Tide go before it stopped?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Almost as far as New-Gravel-lane.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Did the Tide come up as far as Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: It slowed over at some Tides.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What did it at usual and common and ordinary Tides?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: It never came so high.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How high did it come then?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Hard by it came.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How near?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Within Forty Foot upon reasonable Tides.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And did that help to turn this Mill?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Yes; it went to the Dam, and so it drove it.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Where was your way from North to South?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: At Foxes-lane.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was there a Bridge there, over which the Carts went into the Lane, under which the Water did run?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Yes; there was.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What is it that lies beyond the Mill?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Which was further Eastward, Cock-hill or the Mill?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: So it is by your own Map; and then where can the Mill-bank be but Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Shad-well is our Bounds.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Robin Hood upon Greendale stood, therefore this must be your Land: That is all the Argument I can make of it. Your Boundaries do make it as plain as the Nose in a Man's Face.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Swear Mr. Holwell— [Which was done.]—How long have you known this Place, the Lands in Question?

sp.speaker: Holwell.
sp.p: Not above a Year.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: He is your Surveyor, I think.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: He is so, my Lord. Pray you Cope, which way did the Water go?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Westward.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But which way did you use to go to the River from the Lynches?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: We sometimes went the lower way, and sometimes the higher way.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Which was the higher way?

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: And which was the lower way?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Through Wapping and Shadwell: Shadwell is the lower way.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Thou talkest of the Noth-West Way; but if you were to go directly from North to South, which way would you have gone?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Down Cock-hill, or down Broad-bridge.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Where is that?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Beyond Cock-hill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Whereabouts is it?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Within a little of Foxes-lane.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: When you went down Cock-hill upon which Hand did you leave the Mill?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: If I went the lower way, I left the Mill on the Left Hand.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But when you went the higher way down Cock-hill?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Then we left the Mill behind us.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What doest thou mean by behind thee?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: I left it North.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: That could never be, Man.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, my Lord, he is right.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: But I say he is not right, Mr. Attorney, for Cock-hill is North of the Mill.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Cope, do you know Foxes-lane?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Yes, very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Is it raised?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: Yes; Eight or Nine Foot.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: What was the Reason of its being raised?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: It was not fitting for Carts to go over.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Cope.
sp.p: The Water came upon it.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And then to come to the Admeasurement, taking in the Place in question it makes just 130 Acres, which is our Number and no more.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Then you will leave the Dean nothing.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Yes, he has 2000 l. a Year.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Where?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: In the East beyond this Place.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Why, would you have any of the Land that belongs to the Mill?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: we claim this as Marsh-Land; which they have nothing to do with, and the Number of Acres will not be answered without it. Mr. Holwell, have you admeasured the Marsh?

sp.speaker: Holwell.
sp.p: Yes; I have, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: From whence did you begin?

sp.speaker: Holwell.
sp.p: From Hermitage-Dock.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Within what Bounds?

sp.speaker: Holwell.
sp.p: That which they call the Lynches and the Marsh to St. Katherines from the Well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: And how much doth it make?

sp.speaker: Holwell.
sp.p: Besides the Well and the Lynches, I find it something above 130 Acres.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Somewhat above, how much Pr'ythee?

sp.speaker: Holwell.
sp.p: Not an Acre above.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, how many Acres lies East of Gravel-lane?

sp.speaker: Holwell.
sp.p: Besides the Well and the Lynches I can find but Fifty Acres and an half.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Where did you reckon up the whole?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: To make up the 130 Acres, he took in the Mill and all.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: That is very well.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Why, my Lord, it is no more than 130 Acres, and so much we must have.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Look into the Survey that you produced, and see what that says, besides all—

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Those lye eastward of the Mill.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Pray did you measure the Wall?

sp.speaker: Halwell.
sp.p: Wapping Wall is 20 Acres.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: If they will consent, the Jury shall have the Survey with them.

sp.speaker: Mr. Williams.
sp.p: With all our Hearts, let them have it.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Gentlemen, both sides consent, you shall have the Survey with you; but without that Consent you could not have had it, it not being under Seal.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Then we desire our last Verdict may be read. Mr. Sutton, was it a Verdict upon full Evidence?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: How many Hours did it last?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: Five or Six.

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: Was there a View in it?

sp.speaker: Sutton.
sp.p: There was so.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Read it — [Which was done.] — Mr. Holwell, how much pray, is the Land between Foxes-lane and the Mill?

sp.speaker: Holwell.
sp.p: Below the Lynches I find it to be Seven Acres and an half.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: Can you expect then that all those Words of Gardens, Orchards, &c. should be answered under seven Acres and an half. Besides, the first and ancient Reservation of Rent was 10 l. a Year, after it was increased to 16 l. a Year, and it doth appear the Mill turned to so little Account that it was pulled down, and so the Land was to answer the Rent, which for a ground-rent upon a Church-Lease in those Days was very great. Have you done now?

sp.speaker: Mr. Att. Gen.
sp.p: We have done for the present, my Lord.

sp.speaker: L. C. I.
sp.p: What say you to it then for the Plaintiff, Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Mr. S. Stringer.
sp.p:
May it please your Lordship, and you Gentlemen of the Jury; If we should give no further Evidence at all than what we have already given: But leave it upon this, I dare affirm it plainly appears that they have no Title at all to this Land. As to their last piece of Evidence I would first give an answer to that, and that is their Verdict; and that which I would observe upon it, and say to it, is this; it was a Verdict obtained upon forged Deeds. Deeds found, as is pretended, and as you have heard from their two special Witnesses, in a very extraordinary manner found in a Garret. But by what Art prepared, and that they are forged I question not but we shall give you Satisfaction. But besides, as to their Admeasurement, it seems as they would have it 130 Acres is the Question about the extent of the Marsh. So much they claim, and we shall bring two Surveyors that will give you an account upon their Oaths, that between Foxes-lane, which we say is the West Boundary of our Land, and the East of theirs, and Hermitage-Dock, where the Marsh ends, there is above 130 Acres, and so they do not want their Number. For all the Evidence that they have given out of Records, we agree them to be as they say, and by that Agreement shall do our selves no harm at all; for they all do confirm our Assertion: They place the Eastern Bound of the Marsh at Ratcliff-Town; now at Foxes-lane doth Ratcliff-Town begin. The Art has been to confound the Cause by puzling Boundaries, when it is a plain apparent mistake they run upon, and indeed I may very well say, a wilful one too. They would have us confine all to a Mill and a little Ditch, when they are at least seven Acres always enjoyed with it, and all called the Mill, which had a Pond, Gardens, Orchards, Tenements, &c. And now there are very large Drains necessarily made, to keep the Water from annoying the Inhabitants, and to carry it away. But for a further Evidence of our Title, we shall first prove that upon a Bill exhibited in the Exchequer by Mr. Attorney General against Stepkins their Ancestor, to know what Incroachments had been made, what belonged to the Dean of Pauls, and what to Mr. Stepkins, are fully set out. There it is proved that the Bounds of the Marsh were Wapping-wall, alias Foxes-lane. The Marsh was continually overflown with Water, but now in our Ground there was a great many Ditches and places to keep the Water for the Service of the Mill. When we come to build upon our Ground, which was 15 Iacobi (then it began) then he brought an Action and did pretend that we did incroach the Wall somewhat into the Marsh, there we had a Verdict upon a View, and after a Non-suit upon full Evidence.
